review_title: Meaningful work to support the nurses who provide care to people with cancer
job_title: Clinical Sales Representative in Essex, VT
pros: Working at ONS means that every day you make a difference in the life of a person with cancer. Additionally, the flexibility of remote work, the strong commitment to DEI efforts and the strong benefit and wellness programs are exceptional.
cons: Frankly, I just can't think of any.

pros: Flexibility and a commitment from the organization to remain remote, open to hearing different ideas, benefits and PTO are top notch, staff commitment to the mission is great. Little to no expectation to work outside of typical office hours.
cons: Can’t really think of any

review_title: Work life balance in toxic workplace
pros: Full-time remote work, options for four day work week, flexibility in scheduling.
cons: Expectation to be available outside work hours. Passive aggression. Lack of direction from leadership. Not paid commensurate for experience and education.

review_title: Great Company, Flexible Scheduling, and Great Benefits
pros: Work/Life balance, FDWW/flexible scheduling, remote, generous PTO, family oriented, tuition reimbursement, continuing education, strategic goals for company.
cons: Company size-availability for career advancement.

pros:
Flexible WFH environment
Work/Life balance is great
cons: Communication breakdown with some departments, however, most are great.

pros: Great Team manager and co-workers
cons: I did not have any cons

pros: Tons of time off and amazing continuing education benefits
cons: Senior leadership is only interested in hiring their nurse friends to fill business roles that they are unqualified for. Extremely low pay. 10% of the people do 90% of the work.

pros: The people in the group I worked with was great! Work flexibility.
cons: Constant changes. Positions being eliminated or changing all of the time with people being let go regularly. Tough environment to feel any job security. Almost all of the people from my group have been let go or been moved w/o consult to other position, including the Executive I worked for. Upper management gave the illusion of caring but they are cut throat.

pros: Nice group to work with!
cons: Newer departments so processes are still being created

pros: Work-Life Balance; good benefits; flexible telecommute schedule
cons: Minimal room for growth in the organization

pros: Kind people; flexible work environment
cons: Lower pay, skillsets of some employees are below normal professional standards

pros:
- work life balance
- work environment
- management
cons: - would prefer to have more private cube space.

pros: ONS offers great flexibility including a focus on work/life balance, telecommuting, and flex time. They allow four-day work week as well. For a smaller company, the financial and health benefits are generous. They try to keep up on current technology (even though they don't roll it out well).
cons: The leadership is not trustworthy. They tend to be secretive, and make decisions without non-Executive feedback, which can alienate those who are below director level. For example, they jumped on the "open workplace" bandwagon trend, and decided to completely remodel the office. But they are completely disregarding that this does not work for all types of jobs and does not work for all people's working style. Those on the committee making decisions will all have offices still, so their perspective is in a silo. The one person on the committee that does not have an office arranged it so she has an empty cube next to her. Meanwhile most of us are moving into very small, very cramped workspace (not ideal for those of us who talk on the phone or work more independently and need quiet or privacy). The architect they hired is an arrogant elitist, who is blatantly disrespectful to those not in an office, but cares more about "his aesthetic" than actual functionality.

pros: Benefits including wellness campaigns (e.g., massages, boot camp, eating healthy), flexible telecommuting schedules, paid time off (PTO) the week between Christmas and New Years (in addition to earned PTO), and monthly updates on company
cons: There has been significant turnover in the last 11 months for staff nurse positions (3 out of 4 positions). The Director does not realize how her management style affects the team dynamics. The Director attempts to over compensate by showing favoritism to the new hires and then not speaking to staff unless it is to criticize the work. Lucky for me that the Director has not spoken to me for more than three months. There is no recognition for accomplishments (e.g., decreasing a work process from 6-8 hours to 2-3 hours) and no opportunity to express criticism without suffering the Director's wrath.

pros:
My time at ONS has been great so far. They have an incredible company culture. They accommodate flexibility, a great work-life balance, and encourage everyone to be involved at different levels of the organization. 

I've worked at a few other companies in the past, notably ones that never treated their employees like professionals. I've found that ONS respects those they hire and engenders them with a sense of responsibility while remembering that their employees are people--not simply drones to be ordered around.
cons: Some introductory training on the software and systems they use could be standardized more. But honestly, it's hard to find a con in my opinion.

pros: I've worked at ONS for 13 plus years and have had a good experience overall. I've met some of the nicest people working here and some have kept in touch as friends long after they have moved on to other places. The pay is excellent and they have wonderful benefits including flexible work hours and telecommuting. The building is beautiful and provides not only a lunchroom but "wellness" rooms that can be used if you have a health issue, an outdoor patio for lunching, and exercise facilities.
cons: I'm not a fan of the recent reconstruction which is geared toward the open floor plan popular these days. This makes the working atmosphere noisier and more disruptive.

review_title: A good company, with some limitations
pros: Great benefits package (a rarity for non-profits). Good work-life balance with flexible scheduling, telecommuting, and little required overtime, but all of that varies across teams and positions. Generally transparent executive leadership. The company has a rewarding mission and most members you encounter appreciate the work you do.
cons: Some departments seem to give plenty of promotions, while others stagnate. In recent years, ONS tends to go with outside hires rather than promote internal candidates, which has led to an undercurrent of low morale, despite generally manageable workloads and decent benefits.

review_title: Excellent job, didn't even feel like work
job_title: Technical Lead Software in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
Incredible work/life balance
Incredible CE opportunities
Incredible pay for non-profit organization
Incredible co-workers
cons: I worked at the Oncology Nursing Society for roughly four years and have very limited complaints about the work environment. A lot of people that have been unsatisfied in the past did not work at other companies. ONS will literally bend over backwards to help you out in the majority of cases.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Short workdays (seven hour days), It's a great place if you are a pregnant woman because they give you a lot of time off for that.  Also, you get a large number of days off for vacation.  The office building is rather new and stylish in a good location near many of the better shopping locations in the Pittsburgh area.
cons:
Low pay.
Lack of respect from management.
Too much money that could be spent on improving compensation is instead spent on corporate parties and luncheons.

review_title: Great Company With Opportunities for Personal Growth
pros: ONS is truly a great place to work. Employees enjoy great work/life balance and take part in meaningful work supporting oncology nurses. I've had great bosses who have mentored me and helped me move up in the organization. They really try to promote from within and help employees succeed. Many ONS employees have been there for 10+ years, and it's easy to see why.
cons: Compensation is on the lower side in comparison to for-profit organizations, but the benefits, work/life balance, and culture of the company make it well worth it.

pros: ONS provides invaluable resources to oncology nurses worldwide, which greatly impacts the care they can offer their patients.  Great work/life balance.   Supportive and personable staff including all Chief Officers.  Management is invested in its staff and the mission of the company and you feel it!
cons: The open floor plan can contribute to noise at times.

pros: ONS provides an extremely valuable service that positively impacts the lives of cancer patients. Good employee benefits (PTO, telecommuting options, 401 K match, relatively relaxed dress code, etc.). Senior management really tries to treat employees fairly and create great work environment. Nice building and facilities. Professional yet not too informal work atmosphere.
cons: None come to mind. Honestly.

pros: It's a very collaborative, supportive environment to work. In my time at the company I've worked with staff who are happy in their jobs and continually looking for ways to grow and learn.
cons: I haven't had any significant cons in my time at ONS.

pros: Provides a good work / life balance with telecommuting options & significant PTO plans pending your years of service with the company.
cons: Low compensation despite the claim to benchmark annually; no opportunities for growth and advancement.

pros: flexible scheduling, positive culture, fair pay and benefits
cons: I don't have any cons to add.

job_title: Assistant Director, Marketing Communications Management in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Great mission, working with volunteer nursing leadership was inspiring.
cons: Adoption of new management principals could be a tough sell.

pros: Flexible scheduling, remodeled offices, and nice employees
cons: Limited advancement opportunities for professional positions

pros: Work life balance, benefits are pretty good
cons: Pay is a little low
